title: The Inverse Function Theorem
text: The Inverse Function Theorem is $$g'(x)=\frac{1}{h{\left(g{\left(x\right)}\right)}}$$ where g(x) is the inverse of f(x) and $$h(x)=f'(x)$$ or in other words h(x) is the derivative of f(x).

title: Finding the Inverse of f(x) at $$a=0$$.
text: To find the inverse of f(x) where $$a=-8$$, then we need to first find what value of $$x$$ when we plug it into f(x) will give us a value of $$-8$$. In this case, it is when $$x=\frac{1}{3}$$, so we know that $$g(-8)=\frac{1}{3}$$ where g(x) is the inverse of f(x).

title: Finding the Derivative of f(g(x)), where g(x) is the inverse of f(x).
text: We found that the inverse of f(x) $$=\frac{1}{3}$$ in the previous hint, therefore we need next know what $$\operatorname{f'}\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)$$ equals, which is given to us, it is $$2$$.

title: Applying the Inverse Function Theorem
text: Since we know that $$h{\left(g{\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)}\right)}$$ where g(x) is the inverse of f(x) and h(x) is the derivative of f(x) equals $$2$$, we can can apply the inverse function theorem by doing 1/(our answer). In this case this is $$\frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{2}$$.
